title: Sinusoidal Modeling - Orbit of Venus - Part A

content.description:
The planet Venus orbits the Sun every <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>225</mn> </math> days. Because of its elliptical orbit, the distance between Venus and the Sun periodically increases and decreases. The maximum distance of Venus from the Sun is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>108.9</mn> </math> million kilometers, and the minimum distance of Venus from the Sun is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>107.5</mn> </math> million kilometers. The planet reaches each of its maximum distance and minimum distance from the Sun once every <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>225</mn> </math> days.

The sinusoidal function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>D</mn> </math>, given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>D</mi> <mtext> </mtext> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>cos</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>b</mi> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mi>c</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44D7@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, models the distance, in millions of kilometers, between Venus and the Sun as a function of time <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>t</mn> </math>, in days. Based on the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>D</mn> </math>, Venus is at its maximum distance from the Sun at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIWaaaaa@3902@</annotation> </semantics> </math> days.
content.question:
Part A

Use the given information to find values of constants <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>a</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>b</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>c</mn> </math> in the expression for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>D</mi> <mtext> </mtext> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadseacaaMi8UaaiikaiaadshacaGGPaaaaa@3AF5@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Construct new functions, using transformations, compositions, inverses, or regressions, that may be useful in modeling contexts, criteria, or data, with and without technology.
